text: “Mermedus feeds — and we must keep him full.”
Gröftur is the mouthpiece of Mermedus, and his sermons are delivered in drowned tongues, with offerings of flesh, rope, and black salt.
Fiskauga — “Fish-Eye” — is both a name and a curse. Gröftur’s gaze sees into the soul, into guilt and weakness.
Fishermen whisper that he can command sharks to hunt ships. Soldiers fear the tide when he walks the beach. And nobles… they simply go missing.
Teeth like iron, eyes like oil — it does not eat. It punishes.
The cult of seaborne madmen, deep-mutants, and druidic drown-priests who infest coasts and deltas with salt, rot, and ruin.
Scaled and sodden, he reeks of salt and old blood. He wears sea-rags and driftbones.
There is no mercy in Mermedus, and less still in Gröftur. His faith is absolute.
Eyes like fish, skin like kelp — and a voice that summons the drowned.
Pray the tide takes your ship. The cult takes far worse.

Beneath the waves, they chant to the Deep God — a hunger older than Chaos, demanding offerings of blood, bone, and drowned breath. His servants walk the shore in salt-crusted rags, bearing hooks, kelp, and madness.
Having commanded the most staunch of shieldwalls, Geimdall knows timing is everything when it comes to raising those shields.
Sharks kill to eat. The Fang-blades kill to please.
A vessel of legend, Drakkenguard was built from the ribs of a leviathan felled by Bjornling warriors and bound with iron said to be blessed by the gods. It does not sail—it hunts.
The finest Huscarl from the legendary settlement of Oseberg rallies at the thought of timeless battle, hardening his resolve at every blow delt and recieved.

Foul with salt-crust and still damp with offerings, the Brinefangs are sacred relics of the cult — twin shark-tooth sabres pulled from the rotting jaws of the Sea-Father’s first Leviathan. Bound in skin-twine and teeth, each blade was tempered not by flame, but by submersion in sacrificial blood under a new moon. Brinefangs are not forged for balance, nor elegance. They are ritual implements, designed to rip, tear, and poison.

Gröftur Fiskauga was not always a prophet. Once, he was merely a deep-sea scavenger — a fisher of wrecks, half-mad and soaked with brine. But after vanishing beneath the waves for thirteen days during a storm, he returned changed. His eyes — bulbous, pale, and unblinking — see truths others cannot. He claims to have stood before Mermedus, the Shark-God, and received a mission: to drown the false world above and raise a new one, barnacled and blessed. Now, he leads the Servants of Mermedus: a cult of seaborne madmen, deep-mutants, and druidic drown-priests who infest coasts and deltas with salt, rot, and ruin.
Scraped his slime off the hull, didn't we?
Risen from shipwrecked depths, it hunts where corpses drift.
A white belly breaching from below — then blood.
Twice the size, thrice the rage — Gröftur now wears the shape of his god: hulking, finned, and soaked in salt-blood.

Once a sodden prophet muttering gospels to the tide, Gröftur Fiskauga now is the tide. His body has twisted under the unholy eye of Mermedus, swollen with seawater, layered with slick hide, and crowned with jagged fins. His head has taken the shape of a monstrous shark — all teeth, hate, and hunger — and his voice no longer carries riddles, but thunder. Gone is the slouching preacher; in his place stands a creature of the deep: scaled, gilled, and cloaked in seawrack. He walks with the weight of the ocean behind him, smashing through formations like a living tempest. Each swing of his coral-laced weapon leaves trails of blood and salt. He no longer spreads faith with words — he spreads it through devastation.
Risen from shipwrecked depths, Dregmaw hunts where corpses drift.
A spectral jaw closes, dragging the marked soul toward the deep.

This necklace bears ten ancient shark teeth, each yellowed, jagged, and inscribed with glyphs only the drowned can read. The Tenth Tide refers to a ritual massacre in the age before maps, where ten longships full of thralls were dragged beneath the waves as an offering to Mermedus. None returned. But the next morning, the tide delivered these teeth to shore — perfectly arranged in the shape of a maw. Woven into sinew cord and soaked in sacred brine, the Teeth of the Tenth Tide pulse with the rhythm of the sea. When worn, the air grows wet and heavy, and whispers are heard through conch and foam. The relic is a mark of divine favour — and a warning. To wear it is to be seen by Mermedus.

The sea stirs in their blood, and every strike lands with crashing fury.
An unstoppable surge of brine and bone that leaves nothing standing in its wake.
With every strike, the skin toughens — barnacles blooming in defence.
Blessed by the Sea-Father to endure, to crush, and to drag down.

Harrowfin is no ordinary sea-beast. It is said to have been born not of reef or womb, but of prayer — a living monument to the durability and cruelty of the deep. With a skull shaped like a wave-worn anvil and hide like blackened reef-stone, Harrowfin swims through battle with eerie calm. Blades glance off its barnacled skin. Harpoons snap. Even fire struggles to leave a mark.
Ability: "Gift of Mermedus" after being bestowed Mermedus' Blessing
Wounds vanish beneath ridged growth, thick as sunken hulls and sharp as broken oars.
Named after the whirlpool it once emerged from. Its bulk turns tides. Its hunger empties coasts.

Maulkern is no mere sea-beast. It is a nightmare dredged from the crushing dark beneath the western ice trenches, where not even daemons dare swim. First sighted when it rose from a seething whirlpool — the Maulkern Pit — and swallowed an entire Bjornling longship whole, it has since become the whispered terror of sailors and prophets alike.

From salt-stung cliffs and kelp-choked halls, they rise bearing the Sea-Father’s creed. Their blades drip brine and sacrifice; their prayers drown louder than storm or surf. They do not trade. They do not build. They drag the world back to the deep. Mermedus calls — and the tide answers in blood.
From the shallows, his limbs rise — wet, coiling, inescapable.
Salt awakens something ancient — rage shaped by tide, sharpened by hunger.

The Galleon’s Graveyard is no place for the living. Shattered hulls lie twisted like bones beneath the waves, the wreckage of Elven skycutters, Bretonnian warships, and black-flagged pirates alike — all claimed by the Sea-Father’s hunger. Here, in this salt-choked tomb of empires, Gröftur Fiskauga begins his sacred hunt. From the decks of his kelp-bound fleet, he watches as rival sea-lords arrive, daring to plunder Mermedus’ domain. But the sharks stir. The tide thickens. And blood is promised. Gröftur does not conquer — he drags the world down, one vessel at a time. The Deepgod waits. Feed him.

The tide is thick with salt and portent. Fish beach themselves. Waves crash against the rocks in unnatural rhythms. Mermedus watches — not as a god content with prayer, but as a predator awaiting tribute. Your fleet is ready. Your sharks are hungry. Now is the time to begin the rites of offering. Sink the unworthy. Drown the landborn. Spread his shadow like an oil slick across the sea. Earn his favour — or vanish beneath it.
